posts.name: Barkın Var
posts.cooked:
We are making a new robot cart inspired by 1678’s cart. However, we are not sure about the wheel configuration. Which configuration does your team prefer? Is 4 swiveling casters config hard to control?

IMG-20211216-WA0003 1600×900 298 KB

IMG-20211216-WA0003 1600×900 298 KB

IMG-20211216-WA0003 1600×900 298 KB

posts.name: sanddrag
posts.cooked: Do you ever shop at Ikea?

posts.name: Barkın Var
posts.cooked: It has been a long time since I shopped at Ikea but I remember their carts. I think they were easy to control but i am not sure the situation will be the same for an frc event.

posts.name: tjwolter - Mentor, supply clerk and chief janitor Team 5826
posts.cooked: Team just did a refurb on our old cart.  2 fixed, 2 swivel is decidedly the more stable configuration.  The main function of such a cart, beyond the obvious of course, is to glide through doorways with a robot and one inch clearance either side.  Even a little shimmy is, imho, undesirable.
posts.display_username: tjwolter - Mentor, supply clerk and chief janitor Team 5826

posts.name: CharlesM479
posts.cooked: We really like our swerve cart. Some of the off season events we have to go through doors and it just makes it so much easier. We typically put someone in front to help guide the way.

posts.name: Mark Wasserman
posts.cooked:
This is a tough one.

2 wheel corner faster, run straighter, more predictable when turning.  Way easier for 1 person to control.

4 wheel is more maneuverable which is nice if the cart is long and has to go around tight corners.  Really should have 2 people controlling.

Ours is 4 wheel and even though I’m not a fan of needing 2 people to safely navigate, due to it’s length, it would be hard to maneuver in the pits with 2 wheel.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Not fast swerve, but good swerve driven quickly

posts.custom_user_title: Not fast swerve, but good swerve driven quickly

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked:
A cart with 4 swiveling casters is much harder to keep going in a straight line, especially on uneven surfaces like what you will find outside. See if you can find casters where the swiveling can be locked out. If not, you may want to add a second, removable handle at the other end.

Regardless, it is helpful if at least 2 of the casters have a brake to keep the cart in position. Also make sure the wheels used are at least 3" in diameter. Otherwise, you will have trouble going over door thresholds and any rough surfaces outside.

You may also want to go through several years of robot design rules to find the greatest maximum starting height and make sure your cart can still fit through standard doorway with such a tall robot on it. Make sure you include the height of your casters. There is offer a metal strip in the doorway that reduces the effective height of the opening. My friends team had to take their tall robot off the cart to get through the doorway every time they went between the pits and the competition gym at one event.

Edited to add: to get the best of both worlds, use 2 non-swiveling casters at the back end then add a pair of “lifting casters” for manoeuvrability. Lifting casters are typically used to make large pieces of shop equipment like table saws mobile.

Maneuver your heavy workbench with ease using our Workbench Caster Set!

Price: USD 65.99

posts.name: Barkın Var
posts.cooked: Only events my team attends are Turkey Regionals and Champs. That is why, i don’t think that we will have any problems with the doors.

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked: Have you checked the height already? What if they change venues?

posts.name: tjwolter - Mentor, supply clerk and chief janitor Team 5826
posts.cooked: Events factor doorway size into their logistics.  But just try doing outreach visits in all sorts of venues and you will come to appreciate doorway dimensions!
posts.display_username: tjwolter - Mentor, supply clerk and chief janitor Team 5826

posts.name: Barkın Var
posts.cooked: I checked it, the height and width of the cart is in the limitations.

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked: Thoroughly checking for constraints like this and making sure your design can accommodate them is part of a thorough engineering process.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: IMHO the most important part is to get BIG casters!  Bigger than you think you need!  Remember that you will have to push this over a cable cover at some point…  All the Texas competitions have BIG bumps.  We upgraded (twice) to get to 8" casters in our team color (orange) and reached a “almost completely happy” level of drive-over-it ness.  Also worth considering is two BIG wheels (like BMX tires) fixed at the back and casters on the front.  I haven’t tried that, so YMMV. My programming lead wants a powered robot cart, but my enthusiasm for that is VERY limited. Two good tricks:  velcro some rails on the top to lift your bot off its wheels.  That lets you accommodate different dimensions over time.  You can cut the top off a cheap tool box from HD or Lowes and rivet it into the cart to put your most used tools right at hand.  Use two; one on each side Plan in some way to keep the drawers IN during the road trip, or you will learn how to fix drawers.  I can report that its a PITA to do it

posts.name: 829 The Digital Goats Official Curmudgeon.
posts.cooked: You need to take into consideration that the field crew may have to move you cart at times All swiveling casters may make it difficult for them.

posts.name: Mr V
posts.cooked:
Two wheels and two casters are the way to go. Thank you for bringing this up as I need to find our robot car wheels and replace the front casters.

The cart was originally designed with 2 front wheels and 2 rear casters but when we did a revamp for the 2019 season a couple of students insisted that we go to 4 casters, so I picked up another pair and we installed them. It was clear that it was harder to control and get through tight areas but the one student in particular maintained 4 casters were better.

The best configuration is rear steer just like a forklift, a vehicle designed for maneuvering in tight spaces.

posts.name: Mr V
posts.cooked: That is the one situation where I can see a good case to use 4 casters, it can be slid sideways easily if needed which is great if all you are doing is low speed maneuvering/parking.

posts.name: 829 The Digital Goats Official Curmudgeon.
posts.cooked: For somebody who is expecting it yes. For someone who has to quickly grab it and move it no.

posts.name: Barkın Var
posts.cooked: This is what i was thinking but i still have concerns about doing maneuvers inside the pit since we generally position our cart horizontally but we have to exit vertically.

2 swivel in the back with 2 fixed in the front is the safest and most maneuverable option. We’ve been using four casters in a longer cart and it really needs two people to safely move the cart when cornering. Leads to some not so safe situations when one person is moving it. It’s something we would like to get fixed for next year.

The larger the cart, the harder four casters is to move safely. If you compete in smaller venues the 2 fixed, 2 casters is the best move to keep your cart under control.

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked:
I do not know the supplier that does this, but many of the carts used in some Ford facilities have 4 movable casters with a spring loaded lock that will lock 2 wheels when you are not pulling the release. 20211219_130246 1886×1697 531 KB
